qas.question: Which party has always elevated minority floor leaders to speakership?
Why were republicans upset with Mann?

answers.text: objecting to their private bills on the floor

qas.question: What year did Republicans regain control while Rober Michel was Minority Leader?
What have Republicans always elevated their minority floor leader to when obtaining majority status?
What pattern have Democrats not always followed?
Who did Democrats elect to be speaker in 1903?
How many Demcorats were angry with James R. Mann in 1911?
Who was Frederick Gillett a protege of?

context: Second, <a0_0>Democrats<a0_0/> have always elevated their minority floor leader to <b3_0>the speakership<b3_0/> upon reclaiming majority status. Republicans have not always followed <b4_0>this leadership succession pattern<b4_0/>. In 1919, for instance, Republicans bypassed James R. Mann, R-IL, who had been minority leader for eight years, and elected <b5_0>Frederick Gillett<b5_0/>, R-MA, to be Speaker. Mann "had angered <b6_0>many<b6_0/> Republicans by <a1_0>objecting to their private bills on the floor<a1_0/>;" also he was a protégé of <b7_0>autocratic Speaker Joseph Cannon<b7_0/>, R-IL (1903–1911), and many Members "suspected that he would try to re-centralize power in his hands if elected Speaker." More recently, although Robert H. Michel was the Minority Leader in 1994 when the Republicans regained control of the House in the <a2_0>1994<a2_0/> midterm elections, he had already announced his retirement and had little or no involvement in the campaign, including the Contract with America which was unveiled six weeks before voting day.
